pageProps.body:
The Product Space Conditions the Development of Nations

Hidalgo et al.

A network of products produced around the world is constructed based on the degree of interrelatedness between these products. The authors find that such a network exhibits a core-periphery structure, and that poor countries have empirical difficulties in moving towards more sophisticated regions of this network.

Literature review

  • Does the type of product a country produces matter?
    • Industrial products are suggested to be more economically beneficial than agriculture due to spillover effects (i.e. production of industrial products leads to industrialization, which leads to growth)
  • However, this notion has not been formalized; instead, the level of development of a country's specialization in products has been studied through
    • Factor proportions: ratios between a country's capital, labor, land, etc. Poor countries are unskilled-labor and land heavy; rich countries are capital heavy.
    • Technological differences: products are differentiated by the level of technology required to produce them. A country becomes more developed when it moves to a more technologically advanced product.
  • Traditional growth theory posits that countries develop by moving to more advanced products, and that such a redeployment of resources (land, labor, capital) is always possible
    • However, if the distance between certain products are too large, then such a redeployment would be very difficult

Methods

  • Relatedness of products can be measured in several ways:
    • Proportion of land, labor, and capital needed to produce them
    • Level of technological sophistication
    • Inputs/outputs involved in the product's value chain
    • Requisite institutions for producing the product
  • Instead, they can also be measured by looking at how much they are produced together
    • E.g. countries who produce apples probably produce pears, and it can be concluded that they are similar products
  • Based on this, we have

Model. Product proximity between products iii and jjj.

First define the metric

Definition RCA (revealed comparative advantage) of a country ccc in the production of product iii is given by

RCAc,i=proportion of i in country c’s exportsproportion of exports of i in total world exportsRCA_{c,i} = \frac{\text{proportion of $i$ in country $c$'s exports}}{\text{proportion of exports of $i$ in total world exports}}RCAc,i​=proportion of exports of i in total world exportsproportion of i in country c’s exports​

or, mathematically,

RCAc,i=(x(c,i)∑ix(c,i))(∑cx(ci)xtotal)RCA_{c,i} = \frac{(\frac{x(c,i)}{\sum_{i}x(c,i)})}{(\frac{\sum_{c}x(c_i)}{x_{total}})}RCAc,i​=(xtotal​∑c​x(ci​)​)(∑i​x(c,i)x(c,i)​)​

A country will have an RCA above 1 for product iii if it exports more of product iii than is expected (i.e. than the world average proportion of exports of iii vs. all exports). We expect two products to be closely related if they are produced at the same time, or if they are not produced by the same time, in a single country; thus, define product proximity ϕij\phi_{ij}ϕij​ between iii and jjj as either

P(RCAx,i≥1∣RCAx,j≥1)P(RCA_{x,i} \geq 1 | RCA_{x,j} \geq 1)P(RCAx,i​≥1∣RCAx,j​≥1)

or

P(RCAx,j≥1∣RCAx,i≥1)P(RCA_{x,j} \geq 1 | RCA_{x,i} \geq 1)P(RCAx,j​≥1∣RCAx,i​≥1)

whichever value is smaller, i.e. for all countries, what is the probability that iii is a widely produced product given that jjj is widely produced?

Results

  • The product proximity of 775 product classes were studied and formed into a network, referred to as the product space
  • The product space is clustered. Hierarchical clustering shows that products form several groups, with products within each group being close in proximity and products beetween groups being far away.
  • The product space has a core-periphery structure, with industrial productsa nd chemicals being at the core, agriculture and textiles at the left periphery, and electronics and mining at the right
  • Leamer (1984) performs a similar clustering with relative factor intensities in product production, and obtains similar results
  • Different continents have different specialization patterns. For instance, the Americas occupy the core (industrialized products); East Asia occupies the peripheries, e.g. garments and textiles; Africa occupies the far peripheries

Diffusion of products

  • Countries export new products close in proximity to already-exported products. Studies of Malaysia and Colombia's product spaces between 1980 and 2000 reveal a diffusion process in which the countries tend to produce new products that are closer to existing goods.
  • To test product diffusion, define

Model. Density model of product diffusion. Suppose that a country ccc wants to produce a new potential product jjj which they are not already producing. Define the density of the country's current production structure to jjj as

ωjc=∑ixiϕij∑iϕij\omega^c_j = \frac{\sum_{i} x_i\phi_{ij}}{\sum_{i} \phi_{ij}}ωjc​=∑i​ϕij​∑i​xi​ϕij​​

where ϕij\phi_{ij}ϕij​ is product proximity between iii and jjj, and xix_ixi​ is 1 if RCA(c,i)>1RCA(c,i) > 1RCA(c,i)>1 and 0 otherwise. Density is thus the number of products that are important to ccc (RCA(c,i)>1RCA(c,i) > 1RCA(c,i)>1), weighted by their proximity to jjj. High density means that country ccc has many products which have high proximities to jjj.

  • To illustrate that a high proximity makes the production of a new good more likely, consider transition products from 1990 to 1995: for a country ccc, if product iii was undeveloped (RCA(c,i)<0.5RCA(c,i)<0.5RCA(c,i)<0.5) in 1990 but developed (RCA(c,i)>1RCA(c,i)>1RCA(c,i)>1) in 1995, then it is part of the set of transition products.

  • Let TTT be the set of countries for which a product iii was a transition product. Define the discovery factor for product iii

Hi=average density to i in transition countriesaverage density to i in non-transition countriesH_i = \frac{\text{average density to $i$ in transition countries}}{\text{average density to $i$ in non-transition countries}}Hi​=average density to i in non-transition countriesaverage density to i in transition countries​

or

Hi=∑j=1TωijT∑j=T+1NN−TH_i = \frac{\frac{\sum_{j=1}^T \omega^j_i}{T}}{\frac{\sum_{j=T+1}{N}}{N-T}}Hi​=N−T∑j=T+1​N​T∑j=1T​ωij​​​

  • This ratio is bigger than 1 for 79% of products, showing that average density influences transitioning.

  • Alternatively, upon calculating the probability of transitioning to a new product conditioned upon ϕ\phiϕ, the probability is 15% if ϕ=0.8\phi = 0.8ϕ=0.8 but nearly zero if ϕ=0.1\phi = 0.1ϕ=0.1.

Connectivity of the product space

  • The product space is sufficiently connected. Links with proximity ϕ<0.3\phi < 0.3ϕ<0.3 fully connect the product space.

  • A dynamical model where countries diffuse into products with ϕ>k\phi > kϕ>k for k=0.65k = 0.65k=0.65 or 0.60.60.6 or 0.50.50.5 finds that countries like Korea, which is positioned near the core of the product space (industrial products), diffusion is easy; while for countries like Chile, which are not in the core, diffusion is difficult and slow.
